connector.description: Send requests to external HTTP servers using Apache HTTP Client 4.x.

camel.sink.path.httpUri.name: camel.sink.path.httpUri
camel.sink.path.httpUri.description: The url of the HTTP endpoint to call.

camel.sink.endpoint.disableStreamCache.name: camel.sink.endpoint.disableStreamCache
camel.sink.endpoint.disableStreamCache.description: Determines whether or not the raw input stream from Servlet is cached or not (Camel will read the stream into a in memory/overflow to file, Stream caching) cache. By default Camel will cache the Servlet input stream to support reading it multiple times to ensure it Camel can retrieve all data from the stream. However you can set this option to true when you for example need to access the raw stream, such as streaming it directly to a file or other persistent store. DefaultHttpBinding will copy the request input stream into a stream cache and put it into message body if this option is false to support reading the stream multiple times. If you use Servlet to bridge/proxy an endpoint then consider enabling this option to improve performance, in case you do not need to read the message payload multiple times. The http producer will by default cache the response body stream. If setting this option to true, then the producers will not cache the response body stream but use the response stream as-is as the message body.

camel.sink.endpoint.headerFilterStrategy.name: camel.sink.endpoint.headerFilterStrategy
camel.sink.endpoint.headerFilterStrategy.description: To use a custom HeaderFilterStrategy to filter header to and from Camel message.

camel.sink.endpoint.httpBinding.name: camel.sink.endpoint.httpBinding
camel.sink.endpoint.httpBinding.description: To use a custom HttpBinding to control the mapping between Camel message and HttpClient.

camel.sink.endpoint.bridgeEndpoint.name: camel.sink.endpoint.bridgeEndpoint
camel.sink.endpoint.bridgeEndpoint.description: If the option is true, HttpProducer will ignore the Exchange.HTTP_URI header, and use the endpoint's URI for request. You may also set the option throwExceptionOnFailure to be false to let the HttpProducer send all the fault response back.

camel.sink.endpoint.chunked.name: camel.sink.endpoint.chunked
camel.sink.endpoint.chunked.description: If this option is false the Servlet will disable the HTTP streaming and set the content-length header on the response

camel.sink.endpoint.clearExpiredCookies.name: camel.sink.endpoint.clearExpiredCookies
camel.sink.endpoint.clearExpiredCookies.description: Whether to clear expired cookies before sending the HTTP request. This ensures the cookies store does not keep growing by adding new cookies which is newer removed when they are expired. If the component has disabled cookie management then this option is disabled too.

camel.sink.endpoint.connectionClose.name: camel.sink.endpoint.connectionClose
camel.sink.endpoint.connectionClose.description: Specifies whether a Connection Close header must be added to HTTP Request. By default connectionClose is false.

camel.sink.endpoint.copyHeaders.name: camel.sink.endpoint.copyHeaders
camel.sink.endpoint.copyHeaders.description: If this option is true then IN exchange headers will be copied to OUT exchange headers according to copy strategy. Setting this to false, allows to only include the headers from the HTTP response (not propagating IN headers).

camel.sink.endpoint.customHostHeader.name: camel.sink.endpoint.customHostHeader
camel.sink.endpoint.customHostHeader.description: To use custom host header for producer. When not set in query will be ignored. When set will override host header derived from url.

camel.sink.endpoint.httpMethod.name: camel.sink.endpoint.httpMethod
camel.sink.endpoint.httpMethod.description: Configure the HTTP method to use. The HttpMethod header cannot override this option if set. One of: [GET] [POST] [PUT] [DELETE] [HEAD] [OPTIONS] [TRACE] [PATCH]

camel.sink.endpoint.ignoreResponseBody.name: camel.sink.endpoint.ignoreResponseBody
camel.sink.endpoint.ignoreResponseBody.description: If this option is true, The http producer won't read response body and cache the input stream

camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer.name: camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer
camel.sink.endpoint.lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.

camel.sink.endpoint.preserveHostHeader.name: camel.sink.endpoint.preserveHostHeader
camel.sink.endpoint.preserveHostHeader.description: If the option is true, HttpProducer will set the Host header to the value contained in the current exchange Host header, useful in reverse proxy applications where you want the Host header received by the downstream server to reflect the URL called by the upstream client, this allows applications which use the Host header to generate accurate URL's for a proxied service

camel.sink.endpoint.throwExceptionOnFail.name: camel.sink.endpoint.throwExceptionOnFailure
camel.sink.endpoint.throwExceptionOnFail.description: Option to disable throwing the HttpOperationFailedException in case of failed responses from the remote server. This allows you to get all responses regardless of the HTTP status code.

camel.sink.endpoint.transferException.name: camel.sink.endpoint.transferException
camel.sink.endpoint.transferException.description: If enabled and an Exchange failed processing on the consumer side, and if the caused Exception was send back serialized in the response as a application/x-java-serialized-object content type. On the producer side the exception will be deserialized and thrown as is, instead of the HttpOperationFailedException. The caused exception is required to be serialized. This is by default turned off. If you enable this then be aware that Java will deserialize the incoming data from the request to Java and that can be a potential security risk.

camel.sink.endpoint.cookieHandler.name: camel.sink.endpoint.cookieHandler
camel.sink.endpoint.cookieHandler.description: Configure a cookie handler to maintain a HTTP session

camel.sink.endpoint.cookieStore.name: camel.sink.endpoint.cookieStore
camel.sink.endpoint.cookieStore.description: To use a custom CookieStore. By default the BasicCookieStore is used which is an in-memory only cookie store. Notice if bridgeEndpoint=true then the cookie store is forced to be a noop cookie store as cookie shouldn't be stored as we are just bridging (eg acting as a proxy). If a cookieHandler is set then the cookie store is also forced to be a noop cookie store as cookie handling is then performed by the cookieHandler.

camel.sink.endpoint.deleteWithBody.name: camel.sink.endpoint.deleteWithBody
camel.sink.endpoint.deleteWithBody.description: Whether the HTTP DELETE should include the message body or not. By default HTTP DELETE do not include any HTTP body. However in some rare cases users may need to be able to include the message body.

camel.sink.endpoint.getWithBody.name: camel.sink.endpoint.getWithBody
camel.sink.endpoint.getWithBody.description: Whether the HTTP GET should include the message body or not. By default HTTP GET do not include any HTTP body. However in some rare cases users may need to be able to include the message body.

camel.sink.endpoint.okStatusCodeRange.name: camel.sink.endpoint.okStatusCodeRange
camel.sink.endpoint.okStatusCodeRange.description: The status codes which are considered a success response. The values are inclusive. Multiple ranges can be defined, separated by comma, e.g. 200-204,209,301-304. Each range must be a single number or from-to with the dash included.

camel.sink.endpoint.skipRequestHeaders.name: camel.sink.endpoint.skipRequestHeaders
camel.sink.endpoint.skipRequestHeaders.description: Whether to skip mapping all the Camel headers as HTTP request headers. If there are no data from Camel headers needed to be included in the HTTP request then this can avoid parsing overhead with many object allocations for the JVM garbage collector.

camel.sink.endpoint.skipResponseHeaders.name: camel.sink.endpoint.skipResponseHeaders
camel.sink.endpoint.skipResponseHeaders.description: Whether to skip mapping all the HTTP response headers to Camel headers. If there are no data needed from HTTP headers then this can avoid parsing overhead with many object allocations for the JVM garbage collector.

camel.sink.endpoint.clientBuilder.name: camel.sink.endpoint.clientBuilder
camel.sink.endpoint.clientBuilder.description: Provide access to the http client request parameters used on new RequestConfig instances used by producers or consumers of this endpoint.

camel.sink.endpoint.clientConnectionMana.name: camel.sink.endpoint.clientConnectionManager
camel.sink.endpoint.clientConnectionMana.description: To use a custom HttpClientConnectionManager to manage connections

camel.sink.endpoint.connectionsPerRoute.name: camel.sink.endpoint.connectionsPerRoute
camel.sink.endpoint.connectionsPerRoute.description: The maximum number of connections per route.

camel.sink.endpoint.httpClient.name: camel.sink.endpoint.httpClient
camel.sink.endpoint.httpClient.description: Sets a custom HttpClient to be used by the producer

camel.sink.endpoint.httpClientConfigurer.name: camel.sink.endpoint.httpClientConfigurer
camel.sink.endpoint.httpClientConfigurer.description: Register a custom configuration strategy for new HttpClient instances created by producers or consumers such as to configure authentication mechanisms etc.

camel.sink.endpoint.httpClientOptions.name: camel.sink.endpoint.httpClientOptions
camel.sink.endpoint.httpClientOptions.description: To configure the HttpClient using the key/values from the Map.

camel.sink.endpoint.httpContext.name: camel.sink.endpoint.httpContext
camel.sink.endpoint.httpContext.description: To use a custom HttpContext instance

camel.sink.endpoint.useSystemProperties.name: camel.sink.endpoint.useSystemProperties
camel.sink.endpoint.useSystemProperties.description: To use System Properties as fallback for configuration

camel.sink.endpoint.proxyAuthDomain.name: camel.sink.endpoint.proxyAuthDomain
camel.sink.endpoint.proxyAuthDomain.description: Proxy authentication domain to use with NTML

camel.sink.endpoint.proxyAuthMethod.name: camel.sink.endpoint.proxyAuthMethod
camel.sink.endpoint.proxyAuthMethod.description: Proxy authentication method to use One of: [Basic] [Digest] [NTLM]

camel.sink.endpoint.proxyAuthNtHost.name: camel.sink.endpoint.proxyAuthNtHost
camel.sink.endpoint.proxyAuthNtHost.description: Proxy authentication domain (workstation name) to use with NTML

camel.sink.endpoint.proxyAuthScheme.name: camel.sink.endpoint.proxyAuthScheme
camel.sink.endpoint.proxyAuthScheme.description: Proxy authentication scheme to use One of: [http] [https]

camel.sink.endpoint.authDomain.name: camel.sink.endpoint.authDomain
camel.sink.endpoint.authDomain.description: Authentication domain to use with NTML

camel.sink.endpoint.authenticationPreemp.name: camel.sink.endpoint.authenticationPreemptive
camel.sink.endpoint.authenticationPreemp.description: If this option is true, camel-http sends preemptive basic authentication to the server.

camel.sink.endpoint.authHost.name: camel.sink.endpoint.authHost
camel.sink.endpoint.authHost.description: Authentication host to use with NTML

camel.sink.endpoint.authMethod.name: camel.sink.endpoint.authMethod
camel.sink.endpoint.authMethod.description: Authentication methods allowed to use as a comma separated list of values Basic, Digest or NTLM.

camel.sink.endpoint.authMethodPriority.name: camel.sink.endpoint.authMethodPriority
camel.sink.endpoint.authMethodPriority.description: Which authentication method to prioritize to use, either as Basic, Digest or NTLM. One of: [Basic] [Digest] [NTLM]

camel.sink.endpoint.sslContextParameters.name: camel.sink.endpoint.sslContextParameters
camel.sink.endpoint.sslContextParameters.description: To configure security using SSLContextParameters. Important: Only one instance of org.apache.camel.util.jsse.SSLContextParameters is supported per HttpComponent. If you need to use 2 or more different instances, you need to define a new HttpComponent per instance you need.

camel.sink.endpoint.x509HostnameVerifier.name: camel.sink.endpoint.x509HostnameVerifier
camel.sink.endpoint.x509HostnameVerifier.description: To use a custom X509HostnameVerifier such as DefaultHostnameVerifier or NoopHostnameVerifier

camel.component.https.cookieStore.name: camel.component.https.cookieStore
camel.component.https.cookieStore.description: To use a custom org.apache.http.client.CookieStore. By default the org.apache.http.impl.client.BasicCookieStore is used which is an in-memory only cookie store. Notice if bridgeEndpoint=true then the cookie store is forced to be a noop cookie store as cookie shouldn't be stored as we are just bridging (eg acting as a proxy).

camel.component.https.copyHeaders.name: camel.component.https.copyHeaders
camel.component.https.copyHeaders.description: If this option is true then IN exchange headers will be copied to OUT exchange headers according to copy strategy. Setting this to false, allows to only include the headers from the HTTP response (not propagating IN headers).

camel.component.https.lazyStartProducer.name: camel.component.https.lazyStartProducer
camel.component.https.lazyStartProducer.description: Whether the producer should be started lazy (on the first message). By starting lazy you can use this to allow CamelContext and routes to startup in situations where a producer may otherwise fail during starting and cause the route to fail being started. By deferring this startup to be lazy then the startup failure can be handled during routing messages via Camel's routing error handlers. Beware that when the first message is processed then creating and starting the producer may take a little time and prolong the total processing time of the processing.

camel.component.https.responsePayloadStr.name: camel.component.https.responsePayloadStreamingThreshold
camel.component.https.responsePayloadStr.description: This threshold in bytes controls whether the response payload should be stored in memory as a byte array or be streaming based. Set this to -1 to always use streaming mode.

camel.component.https.skipRequestHeaders.name: camel.component.https.skipRequestHeaders
camel.component.https.skipRequestHeaders.description: Whether to skip mapping all the Camel headers as HTTP request headers. If there are no data from Camel headers needed to be included in the HTTP request then this can avoid parsing overhead with many object allocations for the JVM garbage collector.

camel.component.https.skipResponseHeader.name: camel.component.https.skipResponseHeaders
camel.component.https.skipResponseHeader.description: Whether to skip mapping all the HTTP response headers to Camel headers. If there are no data needed from HTTP headers then this can avoid parsing overhead with many object allocations for the JVM garbage collector.

camel.component.https.allowJavaSerialize.name: camel.component.https.allowJavaSerializedObject
camel.component.https.allowJavaSerialize.description: Whether to allow java serialization when a request uses context-type=application/x-java-serialized-object. This is by default turned off. If you enable this then be aware that Java will deserialize the incoming data from the request to Java and that can be a potential security risk.

camel.component.https.automaticRetriesDi.name: camel.component.https.automaticRetriesDisabled
camel.component.https.automaticRetriesDi.description: Disables automatic request recovery and re-execution

camel.component.https.autowiredEnabled.name: camel.component.https.autowiredEnabled
camel.component.https.autowiredEnabled.description: Whether autowiring is enabled. This is used for automatic autowiring options (the option must be marked as autowired) by looking up in the registry to find if there is a single instance of matching type, which then gets configured on the component. This can be used for automatic configuring JDBC data sources, JMS connection factories, AWS Clients, etc.

camel.component.https.clientConnectionMa.name: camel.component.https.clientConnectionManager
camel.component.https.clientConnectionMa.description: To use a custom and shared HttpClientConnectionManager to manage connections. If this has been configured then this is always used for all endpoints created by this component.

camel.component.https.connectionsPerRout.name: camel.component.https.connectionsPerRoute
camel.component.https.connectionsPerRout.description: The maximum number of connections per route.

camel.component.https.connectionTimeToLi.name: camel.component.https.connectionTimeToLive
camel.component.https.connectionTimeToLi.description: The time for connection to live, the time unit is millisecond, the default value is always keep alive.

camel.component.https.defaultUserAgentDi.name: camel.component.https.defaultUserAgentDisabled
camel.component.https.defaultUserAgentDi.description: Disables the default user agent set by this builder if none has been provided by the user

camel.component.https.httpBinding.name: camel.component.https.httpBinding
camel.component.https.httpBinding.description: To use a custom HttpBinding to control the mapping between Camel message and HttpClient.

camel.component.https.httpClientConfigur.name: camel.component.https.httpClientConfigurer
camel.component.https.httpClientConfigur.description: To use the custom HttpClientConfigurer to perform configuration of the HttpClient that will be used.

camel.component.https.httpConfiguration.name: camel.component.https.httpConfiguration
camel.component.https.httpConfiguration.description: To use the shared HttpConfiguration as base configuration.

camel.component.https.httpContext.name: camel.component.https.httpContext
camel.component.https.httpContext.description: To use a custom org.apache.http.protocol.HttpContext when executing requests.

camel.component.https.headerFilterStrate.name: camel.component.https.headerFilterStrategy
camel.component.https.headerFilterStrate.description: To use a custom org.apache.camel.spi.HeaderFilterStrategy to filter header to and from Camel message.

camel.component.https.proxyAuthMethod.name: camel.component.https.proxyAuthMethod
camel.component.https.proxyAuthMethod.description: Proxy authentication method to use One of: [Basic] [Digest] [NTLM]

camel.component.https.proxyAuthNtHost.name: camel.component.https.proxyAuthNtHost
camel.component.https.proxyAuthNtHost.description: Proxy authentication domain (workstation name) to use with NTML

camel.component.https.sslContextParamete.name: camel.component.https.sslContextParameters
camel.component.https.sslContextParamete.description: To configure security using SSLContextParameters. Important: Only one instance of org.apache.camel.support.jsse.SSLContextParameters is supported per HttpComponent. If you need to use 2 or more different instances, you need to define a new HttpComponent per instance you need.

camel.component.https.useGlobalSslContex.name: camel.component.https.useGlobalSslContextParameters
camel.component.https.useGlobalSslContex.description: Enable usage of global SSL context parameters.

camel.component.https.x509HostnameVerifi.name: camel.component.https.x509HostnameVerifier
camel.component.https.x509HostnameVerifi.description: To use a custom X509HostnameVerifier such as DefaultHostnameVerifier or NoopHostnameVerifier.

camel.component.https.connectionRequestT.name: camel.component.https.connectionRequestTimeout
camel.component.https.connectionRequestT.description: The timeout in milliseconds used when requesting a connection from the connection manager. A timeout value of zero is interpreted as an infinite timeout. A timeout value of zero is interpreted as an infinite timeout. A negative value is interpreted as undefined (system default).

camel.component.https.connectTimeout.name: camel.component.https.connectTimeout
camel.component.https.connectTimeout.description: Determines the timeout in milliseconds until a connection is established. A timeout value of zero is interpreted as an infinite timeout. A timeout value of zero is interpreted as an infinite timeout. A negative value is interpreted as undefined (system default).

camel.component.https.socketTimeout.name: camel.component.https.socketTimeout
camel.component.https.socketTimeout.description: Defines the socket timeout in milliseconds, which is the timeout for waiting for data or, put differently, a maximum period inactivity between two consecutive data packets). A timeout value of zero is interpreted as an infinite timeout. A negative value is interpreted as undefined (system default).
